children.text:
I can't, I can't
begin any other way except to
say that I don't believe I'm
interviewing you, Toi Derricote.

And, uh, it was, it was wonderful
just to see you walking across
the room towards me yesterday.
Wow.

Talking about, you're looking to talk
to me, but I'm looking to talk to you.

Um, you've written a number of works
that, uh, I have been, um, profoundly
moved by, because I, I hear you talking
about women in a very uncompromising way.

In Empress of the Death House,
Natural Birth, Captivity.

And I want to ask you about,
uh, something that I think is
forthcoming, the Black Notebooks.
Yeah, and some
work after that, too.
I'm working on some poems after that.
Right.

The first thing I
wanted to ask is to ask you about
a comment that you made yesterday
in your, uh, before your reading.

You quoted the Gnostic Gospels and you
said, If you bring forth what is within
you, what is within you will save you.

If you do not bring forth what is within
you, what is within you will destroy you.

Could you say more about that
and how that's behind your work?
Um,
I think that

I place a lot of importance
on the body itself.

What, uh, what, what we've learned
about our bodies, as women, as black
women, uh, and a lot of the things

we've learned about our bodies, uh,
the lessons are inside us, and they're
not good lessons about ourselves.

And I think one of the things that is very
important for the writer to do, what the
writer can do for himself or herself, but

also for the larger community, is to, um,
to in some way, um, bring forth some parts
of the identity that have been repressed.
very much.

One of the things that, that
Audre Lorde talks about is, um,
how silence will not save us.

And, um, it seems to me that
shame is, is a way that we keep
things going in the same cycles.

In other words, um, We've been
taught not to talk about certain
things because we're ashamed of

those attributes, those thoughts,
those feelings, those experiences.

Uh, and so our society sort of
rewards us for keeping things secret.

However, the problem with that is
that as long as those secrets remain
intact, we may have an image of it.
That's okay.

Uh, on the, the external, uh,
presentation of ourselves.

And even this is true in our
poetry, too, in our literature.
It, it, it may be all okay on the surface.

But, in some way, we are just feeding into
that same system that is causing internal,
uh, uh, violence, really, to the self.

So part of the way of
breaking that cycle, I think.

is to enumerate, detail, and clarify
what's really going on, uh, inside of us.

And I think art can serve an
important use in that way.

How do you find
people responding to your work?

Um, what I'm thinking is that, I
don't think of the black community
as having very many secrets.

Uh, we may, it seems as though we're,
we're always, uh, being studied.
We're always being discussed.
Our lives are always being talked about.

We're always before this
kind of examining, uh, lens.

And if you're talking about secrecy in
your work, it seems to me that, that you
must be talking about something, Much

more specific than what, uh, we usually
think of when we, when we say secret.
Like,

what, what, what are the, we, what are,
how are we usually, uh, do you think,
uh, put under a microscope?

Well, it seems to me, if,
if we're talking about black women,
black women's lives and privacies have
always been public, it seems to me.
Like what?

Well, if you, if
you're talking about, you have
been talking about issues of color.
Mm hmm.

Um, things that we conceal
with regard to color.
Mm hmm.

Issues of sex, things
that we conceal, secrecies, uh,
related to, to, uh, sexuality.
Mm hmm.

And yet it seems to me that
in those two areas alone, if we think
about the lives of black women, Our

sexuality was, was, was thrown open to
the world during slavery and, and we've
never, we've never recovered privacy.
Oh, I see.
Or in terms of color.
I see.
We are on our surfaces.

We, we've never, uh, had any
kind of concealment there, so.
That's interesting.
How are

these secrets then working
with black women in our lives?
Well, um,
one of the

things I think is, um, that, Um,
there is this way in which we've
been categorized and, and as long

as we fit neatly into that category
of experience, everything is okay.

But in some way, all of us, black
and white, you know, American,
whatever, it's so hard for us to
break out of or see ourselves in more

complicated ways than these, these
ways in which we've, our identities
have been compressed into something.
Uh, well let me, let me say this.

For example, in my, in my case, Uh, I
was raised in a black middle class family
and there was a lot of pressure on me.

I thought there was a lot of pressure
on black middle class, uh, young
women to, to, to be nice girls.

To be, Good girls, sweet girls, to, to, to
be sacrificing girls, to take care of our
families, to raise a strong, uh, uh, to
raise strong children, to give our lives.

But there was a way in which we
were not supposed to be sexual
in any kind of public way.

Um, uh, there, I felt that being
sexual Uh, acknowledging sexuality
was in a way doing exactly what

you're talking about, joining that
stereotyped, um, uh, understanding
of our sexuality as black women.

We were slaves, we were, we were
the ones who were promiscuous,
uh, and in some way our identity.
was to counter, was supposed to counter.
But that, again, was putting us in a box.

Even though we weren't what they said we
were, we still had to be this other thing.

And, um, but you see, what I
think is interesting is that what
I'm beginning to recognize is

there, there was that way in which,
um, I was not supposed to acknowledge
my sexuality in any public way.
But also, things were happening hidden.

That, that, um, for example, black women
sitting around in a group at the kitchen
table with the door closed, talking
about their, their, their sexual lives.

And that was there, but it was
sort of like the hidden parts.

And I'm getting more and more in touch
with how complex our identities are.

Um, and part of the way I'm doing
that is by writing about it.

My second book was about the birth of
my son in a home for unwed mothers.

And what happened there is when I was 19
years old, Um, I got pregnant, at that
time, uh, abortions, you know, weren't,

weren't legal, and a lot of times girls
went away to have children, they came
back, uh, and, you know, they, they, maybe

they gave their child up for adoption
and, and the, and you sort of didn't
acknowledge, uh, what had happened.
Uh, there was a lot of shame around

not, not necessarily having
sex, but being caught.
Caught, yeah.

And so,
uh, I didn't tell anybody.

Uh, my own son didn't know this story
about his birth until he was 17 years old.
Yeah.

Uh, because that was
a very shameful thing.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
In the black, black middle class.
Okay.
To, to, to get pregnant.
Okay.

So then I, I wanted to write a book that
not only acknowledged that, but also
made out of those feelings a work of art.

And part of the thing about making it a
work of art was to say, okay, whatever
wasn't perfect, we can Perfect that in
some way, by creating something beautiful.
Okay,
alright.
So the art will transform.
Yeah.

Um, the things that
we live to, to conceal the past
will actually reveal the past.

What, I remember, um, I think I read
that, that you gave this poem to your son.
Yeah.
And what was his response?
What did he say?
He, he was, he's
wonderful.
He's an artist.
Okay.
You know?
So.

Um, what was so wonderful is he, the
first thing he said is, first of all he
said, I didn't know this had happened.

He said, I didn't know
you suffered like this.

And then, then that was his way of saying
to me, um, I was afraid for him to know
because I thought then he would think.

My mother's not a perfect mother,
therefore I'm not a perfect child.

Because there's that way that we're
constantly trying to be the perfect
person, so that the other person will
think they're the perfect person.
Right.

And to hold
up these images, you know?
Okay.

And that was his way of saying
what you were afraid of.
Don't be afraid of that.

And at the same time, he was saying
to me, I see who you really are.
It was just so wonderful.

It was a great act of the
way our children can save us.

The way we can, I think, um, save each
other through seeing who we really are
and, and, uh, and acknowledging that.
Hearing each
other.

Speaking of children, um, we
were talking yesterday and I wanted to ask
you more about this, this, um, idea of how
adults talk to or do not talk to children.

You were saying you didn't want your son
to know the circumstances of his birth.

Um, I think of when I teach classes,
how many black students do not want
to talk about slavery because they
have white students there in the room.

If it's an all black classroom,
okay, fine, we can talk about that.

But if it's a white classroom
or predominantly white, then
You know,

I don't want to get involved in
this conversation here or now.
Um, or perhaps not at all.

Um, so, I want to come to this idea
of censoring and self censoring.

I'm aware, and I don't know if, if
you, you're very much involved in, in
this, uh, aspect of black literature,
but it seems to me that because black

writers are always talking about these
kinds of painful issue, uh, issues,
the things that you're mentioning now,
that much of the work that is written

by black authors is not being made
available to high school students, for
example, or, or on a restricted basis.

Um, I'd like to ask you about that segment
in the Black Notebooks, um, called the
Teacher's Workshop, and where you're going

with that, and where that work is coming
from, since it's, um, as yet unpublished.

Where are you going with those ideas,
and what's in the Black Notebooks?
Um, Uh, well, I think,
um, one of the things I want to do is, um,

make it possible for, for, uh, when I'm
teaching, make it possible for people
in the room to feel that, um, that, um,

we're, we're not enemies, um, who
are going, the other person is
not somebody who's going to, uh,
stop you from speaking, speaking.
Destroy you if you speak.
Jump on you if you say the wrong thing.

Um, because we're, we're, we try so
hard again to protect our images but
it stops us from developing knowledge

of ourselves and the power of feeling
control of our own identities.

So in some way, I think it's better
if we acknowledge to each other
Hey, okay, I'm not a perfect person.

Uh, then, in some way, I have
a kind of a, uh, mobility, a
flexibility with my own material.

And, uh, I think in a classroom,
you can give that sense of the
great power and excitement that
comes with expressing yourself.
These things that are hard to talk about.
Okay, I want to thank you.
Oh, thank you, Opal.
I've, uh, enjoyed speaking with you.

I want to close, uh, by mentioning a poem
that you have in this book, Captivity,
the poem called The Furious Boy.

And, um, it gives us this idea that
you have asserted that there are
people in the world, you, you quote,

um, a philosopher who says there are
people in the world who absorb evil.

Uh, and they don't know
that they're absorbing it.

Uh, and in fact, eventually
it destroys them.

I think of black women in
relation to, to the world.

I think of black people in relation to
the world having absorbed a lot of evil.

I think that your work will
help us to find the way that
we will not destroy ourselves.

That we will not, in
fact, destroy ourselves.

Be absorb, absorbing of the evil of
others and, and, uh, we'll be able
to do something wonderful instead.
Oh, I hope so.
Thank you.
Um,

I think, uh, also
the op, the, uh, organizers of
this conference, furious Flower.
Oh, yes.

I think that we have
had, uh, the chance to begin these
conversations about art and intent.
Right.
Thank you very much and hope we
all go further.
Thanks.
Thank you all.

Isn't this
a great conference, Haki?

Uh, great in the sense that
this is called Furious Flower.
And are we not all furious flowers?

Uh, coming out of the 60s on out into
the 90s and on to the 21st century.

What do you consider very
important about this conference
here in Harrisonburg, Virginia?

Well, I think
the first thing that it honors, uh,
you know, our, our mother, actually.
Yeah.
Gwendolyn Brooks.
Yeah.

And, uh, the work that she
has done over the years.

And she is so giving in her whole
persona, for this conference to
attract all these poets, I think is
the greatest testament to that giving.
You see
how she's affected all of us.

I think the second thing is that it
brings all of us back together again.

There's been, uh, such a void over
the last, um, um, decade actually.

And I can't remember another venue
where so many, um, Diverse forces
from our tradition, uh, the young, uh,
elderly, um, middle aged, and very young
have come
together.

And so it's kind of a, uh,
a mentoring, uh, for the two
of us with the younger poets.

And of course we get to, uh, to
dialogue with, uh, the poets that
kind of brought us into the fold too.
So it's, it's crucial.

And I think the third thing is
that poetry is not only alive
and well, it's a growth industry.
Ah, yes.
Yes.

And that, um,
uh, we have to Stay on the case.

And I think with these young
poets coming today, that that
will not be too much of a problem.

Do you think the
people here are learning something
significantly while we are here?

I mean, do you think that this is indeed,
uh, a place to come and clap and say amen
or a woman, whatever it is that you say?

Uh, is it a, is it a time you say
there's a resurrection of poetry, yes,
but is there a time for the kind of
what I call serious political poetry?
Uh, that I think Sister Gwen can do?

Uh, and others also talk about and
write about and, and say in a very real
sense, let's continue this dialogue.
Uh, is this a beginning dialogue?
Will this dialogue continue?
How can we continue it?
How can we make sure that it continues?
How can we bring people into our arena?
Uh, the way that we think about the world.

Not that they become robots like us,
but how do we think about the world?

What it really means to be black and
human at the end of the 20th century.
Well, Sonya.

To listen to, uh, your reading, along
with Baraka and, uh, Harper and with Mari
last night, the poets could not, younger

poets could not have felt the kind of
spirit and energy that came from that.
One.

Two, often when poets are clustered
in small spaces among themselves,
you have, especially if there's

not this outside influence, You
have ignorant people talking about
how ignorant other people are.
There's no expansion.

Uh, for instance, uh, the first day
here, a poet gave me a copy of his
book that he had just published.
And I read it the other night.
And it was actually very poor.
Needed a lot of work done on it.

I could have told him that it
needed a lot of work the first day.

But after he had gone to the
workshops, Listened to the poets
read, had, uh, the, the dialogue with
many of the poets, uh, themselves.

I was able to look him in his eye
and said, brother, you know, you
need a lot of work on this book.
You see, you need to go back to school.
You see, wherever it may be and work.
So I think that, that is coming.

Now the political side, it takes
more than a conference like this.

It takes, uh, in many cases, uh, trial and
error by getting in the communities which
we are a part of and actually working

and getting slapped a couple of times
and recognizing everything is not fair.
We need to be black.

in this world, this, you know,
white supremacist world, most
certainly in the United States,
is, in many cases, a battle.
It's a fight all the time.
And you and I know that.
You see, from sunup to sundown.
We
have the scars.
That's right.

But on the other side, we not only have
the scars, we have the, the triumphs too.
Ah.

You see, because
we've not only been able to quote
unquote succeed at what we do, we've
been able to make the success human.
You see,

where, where essentially we are within
this community, we are part of this
community, we're not detached from

this community, we're very, you know,
very, and it's an enduing community.

Um, in, in your work and most
certainly, uh, in my work,
which we both learned from Gwen,
that in

order to stay anchored in that community,
we've got to be there every day.

It's not like passing through, like we
got these pass through leaders, you know,
see, that um, but the whole political
side of it only comes with activity.

You see, all too often, what writers
learn in the academy is that you just
find some nice quiet place and you write.

Now, obviously, the content does not
begin to engage the real world unless you
are engaged in the real world, you see.

And so the poets will have
to essentially get back out
there and deal with the world.
The

joy of, of watching Sister Gwendolyn
Brooke, um, Miss Brooks talk and
read and The joy of also listening
to what she say, what she says today.

Uh, she, she goes places where
many poets are not going anymore.
Uh, and she brings to us, uh, a community.
Uh, our community.
And she says, look at it.

You know, look at this community,
uh, learn from it, uh, understand it.
But I still have hope.

An optimism about this community
that I live in, that I reside
in, that I am a part of.
Um, what do you think then?

Do you think then, when one
hears her, are we moving towards
perhaps a third renaissance?

Um, we've had the first renaissance
called the Harlem Renaissance.

Or, um, we've had the second renaissance
called also the Black Arts Movement.

Uh, we have people who write about this
and don't know what they're talking about.

Um, we have a third
renaissance coming also too.

And I'd like to think about this third
renaissance as one where it will be
Include a lot of people, you know, a

lot of us perhaps who sometimes will be,
uh, secreted in a university someplace
and sending work out for us all to see.

And those who will also secret
themselves also in a community and
will then give us third world press.

You know, and all the things that we
do, but you and I understand that we
have sent out into this world, many of
our own students, you know, who have a

vision, and I would hope that perhaps
we can look at each other in this third
renaissance and say, ah, yes, I like this.

I will make sure this book that you
sent us from this little cubby hole
some place, we'll get to this brother,

this sister, uh, be they black, Chicano,
whatever they be, you know, uh, Puerto
Rican, you know, read that and at some

point let them also explode in some
flowery fashion there in Harlem, you know,
there in Chicago, you know, there in L.

A. Um, I guess what I'm saying that
this third renaissance perhaps will
make us move in a very human fashion
and we will perhaps extend our arms.

to everybody and say, come, taste this,
you know, because we have survived,
we have stayed human, and we can now
extend our, you know, humanity out to

a lot of you who perhaps will never
understand what we've done for the
last 30 years, but okay, but you will
reap the benefits from that, you see.
Well, yes,

and I think, I think that this
third renaissance exists primarily
because of poets like yourself, and

you look at the poets that come out
of the 60s, many of us went into
the academy in order to stay alive.
Mm hmm.

Students cannot
come through my class without
reading your work and the great work
of the other great black writers.

You see, you just cannot
come through this class.

And therefore, I and your work
will make an impression upon them.
You

ee, writers and as well as those who
do not want to write, especially, too.
You got this whole twenty year cycle.

Okay, so you have these young rappers
out here, many going in the wrong
direction, but you got something
going in the right direction.

I think that's a result
of this, this tradition.
The next is We have children in college.
Alright.

My sons and my daughters,
uh, will not have to.

They matured at a much
greater pace than we.
Okay.

I had to find Richard
Wright at 13 years old.

Uh, my sons and daughters were reading,
you know, listening to Richard Wright
and Sterling Brown and, and Gwendolyn

Brooks and Sonia Sanchez and Mari
Evans when they were 3, 4, 5 years old.

They came through an African
Center type education.

Alright, so what we represent, we
represent the institutionalization
of what we write about.

Alright, and so therefore I
think this third renaissance
will be a lasting renaissance.

And it will be more inclusive
and it will be much larger too.
Absolutely.

And Gwen has traveled all,
through all three of them.
Ah, yes.

You see,
so she's a, she's a connector.

And I, and that's
what I wanted to say to you, ask
you to comment on the whole point
of how we try to fixate people.

You know, I watch some of the
critics who say simply that you are
and I am only a black arts poet.

And I say to people, you do realize a
poet who is alive and who is breathing
and who is continuing to write, you know.
I mean, Haki has 13, 14, 15 books.
I have 13, 14, 15 books.

It means that we have
not fixated ourselves.
For instance, look at Gwendolyn Brooks.

Sister Gwen, you know, look at all the
people who write until their last breath.

Look at Baraka, who write
until their last breath.
Mari Evans, we all write.

And so I think that at some point, one of
the things, one of the points we really
want to say at some point is that we've

got to burst through this Eurocentric
way of pigeon hole, pigeon hole, you
know, hole, you know, holing people.

Uh, and say simply, you know, we look
at it in a different kind of fashion.

You know, we are these African
people, you know, and we breathe.

You know, so therefore we
move from just one period.

We might have begun there, but by
golly, by gee, we go throughout.

Well, we're here,
so we know we're beyond these periods.
But if you read the books

No, no, I
understand exactly what you're

saying, that, that, essentially,
that's part of the containment.
Mm hmm.
And

you find that even
now, even within our culture, you have
men and women who have been anointed to
contain, to rewrite, to be revisionists.
Oh, yes, yes, yes.

And so, therefore,
that's going to happen in the books
coming out that we've been revised out of.
Our tradition.

Pigeonholed into, say,
just the decade of the 60s.

Now realizing that essentially a
good many of those brothers and
sisters, yourself, Mari, Baraka,
myself, and others, have continued on.
Building, you see.

But, we will not get the, you know,
the large positions and the large
grants to do that same kind of writing.

And access to the same
type of media, you see.
So, we have to continue to battle.

But it's always a fight,
it's always a struggle.
And

what Gwendolyn Brooks has taught
me more than anything else is that,
just go about and do your work.
Exactly.

It's gonna
be a struggle all the time.

What do you forecast for
For us, if you want to do that, I don't
know about the time, as, as a people.

Uh, for us as writers, uh, are there
different ways that we should explore
things, different avenues we should
turn, uh, different places we should go?
Uh, what do you think about this?

Well, I think
that we're living in difficult
times, but at the same time, we're
living in very promising times.

You remember back in the 60s, there
were approximately eight black
bookstores across the entire country.

At the most, there were about
six or seven black bookstores.

As we speak today, there are about
350 black book stores or people
selling books out of their cars, out
of their homes, out of their cellars.
I
love
that.

And there are
at least 70, 75 black publishers.

In fact, there's a national
publishers organization, National
Association of Black Book Publishers.
So there has been development.

We've got the Gwendolyn Brooks
Center at Chicago State.

And there are other African and Africana
studies departments all over the country.

Now, so, I see that as we attach ourselves
to these departments, to this, to this
movement, that things can only get better.
Now, this is the problem.

The more politicized people become,
the more dangerous they become.

And that has happened with,
in many cases, with the poets.

And so, where we don't see your work,
or my work, or Baraka's work, or Mari
Evans work, or Kalamu ya Salaam's work.
Uh, in the major venues in the country.
Why?

Because essentially, we are
still fighting, in many cases,
the same kind of battle.

And that's why we had to
create our own venues.

But by doing that, we touch
this new generation at a level
that other people can't touch.
Why?

Because they understand the
importance of building what we call
independent black institutions.

You see, whether there are schools,
whether there are health institutions,
or whether there are magazines

or publishing companies, that
that's what we have to be about.
And so I'm encouraged.

You see, I feel very good
about what will happen.
Primarily because I see my own children.
I see your children.

And I see the children of the people
that come through our school in Chicago.

Is that there, there, there is this,
this, this, this new centering.
You see what I'm saying?

That what, what, what black poetry
and what African Center Studies does
is centers us in ourselves, therefore

securing us in ourselves, which allows
us to move out into anybody's world
and not essentially be co optive.
Right.

Okay, and so what
the poetry does, And what it, uh, did
for me has essentially said, look, we
don't have to apologize to anybody.

And what the 60s did, which was
the most important and a decisive
decade, was said that we don't have
to stand in line behind anybody.
We're going to set the agenda now.

And the agenda for any people
who are in control of their own
cultural imperatives, that first and
foremost, they start with themselves.

And when they start with themselves and
are comfortable there and understand
that we not only brought civilization

to the world, we continue to spread
that which is good, just, right.

You see, and when we do that, we
don't have to apologize to anybody.
We just keep on stepping.

And what will happen, the people
that understand the work that
we're trying to do, will say yes.
That's good work.

You see, and that's what happened
here with Gwendolyn Brooks.

You see, twenty five years ago Gwendolyn
Brooks did not have an audience like this.
And we know this.
Oh
yeah.

Twenty five
years ago, Gwendolyn Brooks
was scuffling just to pay rent.
Pay rent.
Okay?

And so we find now that
she stayed on the track.

I hardly remember my mother's face

chill wind, stirring strange longings

for the sturdy back I used to lean
against for warmth and comfort.

When I had grown too tall to ride,
and I am blinded by the glint of
sunlight, striking golden fire from

the flint of sea foamed rocks below me
on some island not too far from home.

After that, the only light I saw
was a few wayward chinks of day that
somehow slanted into the airless tomb.

where chains confined me
motionless to a dank wall.

Then the sun died and
time went out completely.

In that new putrid hell trap of the dead
and dying, the stench of vomit, sweat,
and feces mingled with the uneasy motion
of the ship until my senses failed me.

I do not know how many weeks or months
I neither thought nor felt, but I
awoke one night, or day perhaps,
revived by a consciousness of sound.

I heard the pounding of the waves
against the ship's side, and made
believe its rhythm was the speech of
tribal drums summoning in acute need.

The spirit of my ancestors, I
dreamed I saw their carbon images
arrayed in ceremonial austerity.

I thought I heard their voices
thundering an answer to my supplication.
Hold fast,
survive.
Survive.
And then I slept again once more.
The sunlight came.
But not the same as I remembered it.

Now it sat silver cold upon the
indifferent New England coast.
Still, it was good to see the sun at all.

And it was something to find
myself the bright, dark mascot of
a blind but well intentioned host.

A toy, a curiosity, a child
taking delight in anyone's
attention after so long a death.
As I grew older, it was not enough.

That native life song, once again
burst free, spilled over sands of my
acquired rituals, urged me to match

the tribal rhythms that had so long
sustained me, that must sustain me still.
I learned to sing a dual song.

My father's will forgive me if I lie,
for they instructed me to live, not die.

Grief cannot compensate for
what is lost, they told me.
Win, and never mind the cost.

face the world would see.
